_glossaryItems.description: Personal and often unreasoned judgement based on prejudice. (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course )
Making decisions and taking actions based on fact – and not on biases or personal opinions.

Traditionally, the terms race and colour have been used interchangeably. More recently, it has been used in the context of hierarchies based on the spectrum of skin colour within a racialized group (Joshua Sealy-Harrington and Jonnette Watson Hamilton (2018)."Colour as a Discrete Ground of Discrimination". Canadian Journal of Human Rights: (2018) 7:1 Can J Hum Rts.).
An act of differential treatment toward a person or group, which usually creates a disadvantage for that person or group.  (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course )
The cultural origins of a person’s ancestors (Statistics Canada’s 2006 Census Dictionary).

Any improper conduct by an individual, that is directed at and offensive to another person or persons, and that the individual knew or ought reasonably to have known to would cause offence or harm.  (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course)

An environment or approach that is fair, equitable, supportive, welcoming and respectful. It recognizes, values and leverages differences in identities, abilities, backgrounds, cultures, skills, experiences and perspectives.
Free from any form of discrimination - all CBSA employees shall value diversity and treat every person with respect and fairness.

An opinion or judgement, frequently unfavorable, based on irrelevant considerations, inadequate knowledge or inaccurate stereotyping. (Source: Alberta Human Rights and Citizenship Commission.)   (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course)

Used to refer to a group of people who have some visible physical traits in common, such as skin colour or hair texture. It is a concept developed by society to marginalize people, and has been applied in various ways in different parts of the world and throughout history.

A person is racialized, or designated as being of a particular "race” based on their physical features or other personal characteristics. Deep rooted beliefs in society have associated negative stereotypes with these characteristics – this has led to disadvantages for people with these traits.

The belief in the superiority of one race over others, and any discriminatory forms of behaviour that are engaged against other races based on such belief. (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course)

Any action or decision that treats a person or a group negatively based on race. People in Canada are protected from this by the Canadian Human Rights Act when they are employed or receive services from the federal government.

Any action, taken by one or more people in authority or by an organization for reasons of safety, security, or public protection,  that relies on stereotypes about an individual’s actual or presumed race, colour, national or ethnic origin or religion, rather than factual grounds or reasonable suspicion, to single out an individual or group for greater scrutiny or differential treatment. It is a form of discrimination.
Drawing conclusions about a group of people who have the same characteristics with no differentiation made between individuals.  (see more in the Diversity and Race Relations course)
The social stereotypes about certain groups of people that individuals form outside their own conscious awareness (University of California San Francisco’s Office of Diversity and Outreach).
